figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: The workflow of M-UITA. M-UITA, mask ultrasonic imaging tracking algorithm; R-CNN, region-based convolutional neural networks; RMCS, respiratory motion compensation system.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: The diaphragm phantom. (A) Side view of the diaphragm phantom. (B) Top view of the diaphragm phantom.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Experimental apparatus. (A) The fixture was set on a still surface. (B) The setting of the ultrasound probe. RMSS, respiratory motion simulation system; RMCS, respiratory motion compensation system.

figure_4.title: Figure 4.
figure_4.caption: The overall experiment setup. CT, computed tomography; RMSS, respiratory motion simulation system; RMCS, respiratory motion compensation system.

figure_5.title: Figure 5.
figure_5.caption: Examples of diaphragm images of the dataset.

figure_6.title: Figure 6.
figure_6.caption: The loss curves of the model.

figure_7.title: Figure 7.
figure_7.caption: Screenshots of working M-UITA. M-UITA, mask ultrasonic imaging tracking algorithm.

figure_8.title: Figure 8.
figure_8.caption: The pre-recorded respiratory signals. (A) Sin; (B) Pattern A; (C) Pattern B; (D) Pattern C; (E) Pattern D; (F) Pattern E.

figure_9.title: Figure 9.
figure_9.caption: The tracking trajectory of (A) Sin, (B) Pattern A, (C) Pattern B and (D) CRs with error bar drawn with twice the standard deviation. M-UITA, mask ultrasonic imaging tracking algorithm; CT, computed tomography; CRs, compensation rates.

figure_10.title: Figure 10.
figure_10.caption: The tracking trajectories of: (A) Pattern C compensated with M-UITA; (B) Pattern C compensated with UITA; (C) Pattern D compensated with M-UITA; (D) Pattern D compensated with UITA; (E) Pattern E compensated with M-UITA; (F) Pattern E compensated with UITA. M-UITA, Mask Ultrasonic Imaging Tracking Algorithm; UITA, Ultrasonic Imaging Tracking Algorithm.

claims.sentence: Figure 1 shows the workflow of M-UITA.
Figure 2 presents the design of the diaphragm phantom.
The ultrasonic probe was fixed by a fixture and set on a still surface where was no relative displacement with ground as shown in Figure 3A.
Figure 3B shows the setting of the ultrasound probe.
Figure 4 shows the complete experimental setup.

Open in a new tab
The diaphragm phantom. (A) Side view of the diaphragm phantom. (B) Top view of the diaphragm phantom.Figure 3.
RMSS, respiratory motion simulation system; RMCS, respiratory motion compensation system.Figure 4.
Examples of diaphragm images from the dataset are shown in Figure 5.

The errors were calculated as following:
Figure 5.
Figure 6 shows that the loss curves of the model all have a downward trend, and the errors of the training and validation datasets converge to 0.236 and 0.438.
Figure 7 displays the screenshots of M-UITA in action.
The waveforms are shown in Figure 8.
The respiratory signals are shown in Figure 8.
In Figure 9A, the sine wave tracking signals of M-UITA almost overlapped with the actual displacement, while some defects and jitters existed at the turning point.
Figure 9B, there was a slight translation between the M-UITA and the CT trajectories in Pattern A.
Although there were also defects and jitters like sine wave and Pattern A at the turning point, the M-UITA and the CT trajectories were almost overlap as can be seen in Figure 9C.

DFDs, discrete Fréchet distances.Figure 9.
Figure 9D shows the CRs of the three waveforms, and the error bars were drawn with twice the standard deviation.
Figure 10 illustrates the tracking trajectories of each input signal.
In Figure 10B, it can be observed that in Pattern C, after 70 seconds, the tracking waveform of UITA exhibits a highly unstable state.
